title: Handmade derby boots 1: Drafting the pattern
text:
In a series of posts, I‚Äôm going to share my process for crafting a pair of handsewn, hand-welted leather derby boots.
I‚Äôm absolutely not a shoemaking expert. I‚Äôm fully self-taught, and my process is a weird melange of professional bespoke techniques and idiosyncratic hacks. But I‚Äôve been wearing the first pair of hand-welted derby boots I made every day for nearly a year, and they‚Äôre holding up really well. So whatever I‚Äôm doing is good enough for me!
To create my new derby boot pattern, I‚Äôm mostly following instructions from the book Handcraft Your Own Shoes and Boots by Neda Hussain. I‚Äôve noted other useful references and sources for shoemaking materials at the bottom of the post.

title: Handmade derby boots 1: Drafting the pattern
text:
The process

Cover the last (that is, the foot form) in masking tape and mark essential points.
Cut the tape off the last and stick each side flat onto paper to create the inside and outside forms.
Average out any wobbly bits to create the mean form.
Add on design lines to create the standard form.
Using the standard form, create pattern pieces.


1. Taping the last
Overall, what I‚Äôm doing here is moving from the 3D shape of a last down to a 2D representation. Covering the last in masking tape, then cutting the tape off and sticking it down flat onto some card, gives me a decent approximation of the curves and contours of the foot.







These are my lasts! Only one needs to be taped up if they‚Äôre approximately the same shape. I‚Äôve augmented them with cork where my feet are wider and rasped and sanded them down where my feet are smaller.









One last covered in masking tape. I‚Äôve marked a line down the centre of the foot (and out of view, another black line marks the centre of the heel).


I marked the centre lines down the front and heel, as well as the ‚Äúvamp point‚Äù: the widest point of the last measured from the ball of the foot across to the pinky knuckle. This is also the point where the ‚Äúquarters‚Äù end and the ‚Äúvamp‚Äù begins. The ‚Äúquarters‚Äù are the pieces on each side of the foot and ankle that meet the strap at the centre back and hold all the eyelets for the laces on either side of the front. The ‚Äúvamp‚Äù is the piece that joins the toe cap in the front, curves around the sides of the foot to lie below the quarters, and extends upwards between the quarters to make the tongue.


2. Getting the inside and outside forms
I also marked the ‚Äúcounter point‚Äù CP on the heel, sliced the tape along those two centre lines, and stuck each half down onto card and cut them out.







The tape has been peeled off of the last and stuck down onto card. The VP (‚Äúvamp point‚Äù) and CP (‚Äúcounter point‚Äù) have been marked on tthe instep and heel respectively.


Getting the tape approximately flat is good enough for most of the foot‚Äîthose wrinkles aren‚Äôt the end of the world. But small slices around the outside edge are essential to help the toe lie down smoothly.


3. Finding the mean form
The mean form is so called because it‚Äôs the mean, i.e., average, of the inside and outside forms.







From the last to the mean form: a 2D representation of its shape!


I overlaid the inside and outside forms on another piece of card and traced around each of them. Then I marked the line that falls in between each of those outlines and cut along it (except for the bottom front of the foot‚Äîthere I kept the full width of the outside form).
I only need to do all this once. Now that I have the mean form, I can use it as the basis for every pair of shoes I design for this last from now on.


4. Creating the standard form
Here‚Äôs where things get design-specific and the shape of the derby boot starts to emerge!
This step involves tracing the mean form onto another piece of paper, marking a bunch of points in particular locations, and drawing a bunch of lines between them at specific angles and with specific lengths. I leaned heavily on the Hussain book here!







The standard form is like the first mock-up of the shoe pattern. It‚Äôs the basis for making all the individual pattern pieces.


One place I diverged from the Hussain book: that book is written for making shoes using the stitch-down construction (i.e., the upper of the shoe is sewn directly onto the midsole), a construction that‚Äôs easier to sew but a lot harder to resole. I‚Äôm going to hand-welt my shoes instead (see this Shoegazing post on different construction methods). Hand-welting requires the lasting allowance around the bottom edge to be a lot more generous than stitch-down requires its seam allowance to be. I used 25 mm total.


5. Getting the pattern pieces
Finally, I followed the Hussain book to derive from the standard form the four pattern pieces I‚Äôll cut from my leather.







The four pattern pieces for my derby boots: heel counter with back strap (top left), toe cap (top right), quarters (bottom right), and vamp (bottom left).


For easier tracing, I glued the paper pieces onto card (sourced from a recycled folder, hence the funny ridges!).
That‚Äôs all for now :)

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
Not a lot of what I did in the first year of my PhD was a great use of time‚Ä¶ but I did create a darn good setup for managing my literature that‚Äôs paying off years later.
The key idea: use Google Forms to build a synthesis matrix.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
The synthesis matrix
Imagine a spreadsheet in which every row is a book or paper you‚Äôve read, and every column is a topic that‚Äôs important for your research. If a source says something interesting about a topic, you jot down in that column a quick note or a nice quotation.
Then when the time comes to write a paper about ‚Äúwordhood cues‚Äù, say (yknow, just hypothetically), you can revisit the notes you‚Äôve left in the ‚Äúwordhood cues‚Äù column to see everything folks have said on the topic.
Here‚Äôs an excerpt of mine:
¬†



BibTeX Key
Keywords
Main idea
Wordhood cues




DixonAikhenvald2002a (link)
wordhood, typology
Separately define both ‚Äúgrammatical words‚Äù and ‚Äúphonological words‚Äù
No single phon. criterion for every language. A few gram. criteria that can work for every language.


Haspelmath2011 (link)
wordhood, typology
No criteria for wordhood are reliable cross-linguistically
Discusses applicability of ten (grammatical) criteria


Wray2015 (link)
wordhood, literacy
Intuitions about wordhood are based on orthography and on the prototype of word as concrete noun
Word mainly as orthographic unit



¬†
The synthesis matrix quickly became my favourite way to manage my PhD literature.

It preserves ideas from a paper you‚Äôre reading now but may not actually cite for another three years.
It simplifies writing lit reviews based around ideas (like ‚ÄúCats are good (Author A, Author B)‚Äù) instead of based around authors (‚ÄúAuthor A says cats are good. Author B agrees‚ÄùÔ∏è).
It makes collaborating on lit reviews a breeze: your colleague can enter notes from a source they‚Äôve read, and then you‚Äôve got access to the key points too.

The problem: Entering text straight into a spreadsheet can be such a pain.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
Enter: Google Forms
With Google Forms (or Microsoft Forms, or probably many others‚Äîpick your poison), you can create a ‚Äúsurvey‚Äù that contains a bunch of text fields, each corresponding to a piece of information that you want to record.





Then once you submit this form, the text you entered in each field will be saved as a new row in a spreadsheet.





If you decide after creating the form that you want to start taking notes on a new topic, then it‚Äôs as easy as editing the form to add a new question. A new column will automatically be added into the spreadsheet.

title: Doctors hate this one weird synthesis matrix trick
text:
What to record?
For each source, I record:

BibTeX key
Topics/keywords
Main idea
Data/evidence/method used (e.g., ‚Äúexperiment‚Äù, ‚Äúreview paper‚Äù, ‚Äúnarrative argumentation‚Äù)
Overall impression (e.g., ‚Äúhas great lit review‚Äù, ‚Äúhard to follow‚Äù)
Followup lit (any papers that are mentioned that I should go read)
Followup ideas (questions/ideas that this source raises)

Then I also have many optional questions about the different research topics that I‚Äôm interested in, for example:

Wordhood cues
Rule generalisation
Emergence of compositional structure

Of course not every source weighs in on every topic. I just take notes under the topics that are relevant.

This literature management method has really helped me, and I hope it can help somebody else out there! Happy synthesising üòä

title: Handmade derby boots 2: ‚ÄòClicking‚Äô and ‚Äòclosing‚Äô
text:
Cutting the leather
When sewists cut out their fabric, one thing they have to pay attention to is how their pattern pieces align with the fabric‚Äôs grain. A piece that‚Äôs aligned with the grain doesn‚Äôt stretch, while a piece on the bias (45 degrees to the grain) does. It turns out that shoemakers have to do something similar!
Leather hides also have stretch, but unlike fabric, this stretch goes in different directions on different parts of the hide. And the pattern pieces need to be cut from a part of the hide that puts the stretch in the right places.
Back when I was making my first pair of shoes, I created these diagrams that summarised information about leather stretch that I found online (click to view larger).



The top diagram labels the parts of a hide‚Äîshoulder, bend, butt, and belly‚Äîand indicates which way the stretch of each part runs. The bottom diagram shows how the stretch should be laid out on the foot: you want side-to-side stretching across the front of the foot, and vertical stretching around the heel.


Taking this stretch into account, I traced my pattern pieces using silver pen onto the hides and cut them out (again, click to view each picture larger).









The leather used for the outer layer of the boot is 1.4‚Äì1.6 mm thick calf leather.







I had to work really hard to remember to cut two mirrored versions of each piece!







The lining is <1 mm thick pig skin suede velour.





I‚Äôd estimate that these boots used up about five square feet each of the outer leather and of the lining leather.

title: Handmade derby boots 2: ‚ÄòClicking‚Äô and ‚Äòclosing‚Äô
text:
Skiving the edges
Before I started leatherworking a few years ago, I only knew ‚Äúskiving‚Äù as a Britishism for skipping school. But it also refers to shaving down the edges of the leather pieces in areas where they‚Äôll overlap, so that when they‚Äôre sewn together, the final piece will have a consistent thickness.
Beginner kits will often come with ‚Äúsafety skivers‚Äù, tools that put razor blades at awkward angles so they‚Äôre far away from your fingers. They may be safe, but they‚Äôre also really annoying to use. I got so fed up with my safety skivers during my last pair of boots that I went and bought this definitely-not-safety knife and a whetstone, and boy is that an improvement! A properly sharp knife actually makes skiving fun.



I skived down the areas of underlay on the vamp (and the quarters, not pictured), gradually thinning the leather from about 10 mm in.


Here‚Äôs another skiving tip that improved my life (picked up from the Carreducker blog): skive onto a glass surface. The knife won‚Äôt chew through the glass the way it will a cutting mat. I just use the glass from a thrifted picture frame.

Lining
Here‚Äôs a little photo montage of sewing up the quarters and the heel cap/back strap. (For the lining I cut the vamp and toe cap as one, so no sewing needed there!)









The pattern pieces as cut out. The dots of silver pen along the back edge of the quarters pieces show where the edge of the heel cap/back strap piece will sit.







I used a short, wide zigzag stitch to sew the centre back of the quarters edge-to-edge. To keep the pieces aligned, I found matching these silver pen markings every inch or so really helpful.







Before sewing the back strap piece onto the quarters, I glued it on to keep it secure. I use contact adhesive (water-based, no thank you to toxic fumes), so both surfaces need to be gluey for them to stick together.









The back straps are glued on, ready to be stitched down. I love how these pieces look like weird sea organisms.







I again used a short, wide zigzag over the edge of the back strap piece to secure it to the quarters.

text:
Sewing the outers by hand
I followed a similar order of operations for the outers as for the lining.









With dividers (unsung hero tool of shoemaking), I marked 3mm in from the centre back edge of the quarters and punched holes using these 3 mm pricking irons.







To sew the quarters edge to edge, I‚Äôm using the ‚Äúx and bar‚Äù stitch (or x-bar stitch, a lil linguist humour there) from the Hussein book.







The outside has horizontal bars, and the inside has the Xs. In the end these stitches will be covered up by the back strap.









I‚Äôve created more sea creatures by gluing all the bits together in preparation for sewing.







I‚Äôve punched holes about 3mm from the edge of each piece and saddle-stitched through them. This photo also shows the inside of the x-bar stitch.







I also punched holes and saddle-stitched the toe caps to the vamps.





I also sewed up the dart at the centre back of the heel, and glued the seam allowance open.
Finally I taped over all the seams for reinforcement.









Before taping‚Ä¶







‚Ä¶ and after!





The tape isn‚Äôt for reinforcing the seams, necessarily‚Äîsaddle-stitching is actually hardier than machine stitching. Rather, I like to use it in case the thinned-out leather fails.
On my last pair of boots, the leather of the quarters around the heel cap did actually wear through (because of my inconsistent skiving with the old safety skivers). title: Handmade derby boots 3: Preparing insoles and welts
text:
The insoles
The insoles are not just the layer on which the foot will rest‚Äîthey‚Äôre also the anchor that‚Äôll hold the whole shoe together.
The first step is to block the insoles to the bottom of the last so that the leather begins to take on the curve of the sole. I cut some generously sized pieces of 3 mm veg tan leather, immersed them in water, let them dry until they were just a little bendy, scraped the skin side with a piece of glass (glassing removes the outermost surface to hopefully lessen squeaking as I walk), and nailed the pieces onto the last.



The veg tan leather is nailed skin side up to the insole. The nails around the edge help force the leather up against the ‚Äúfeather edge‚Äù, the bottom perimeter of the last.


Being able to find the feather edge is crucial, because the next step is to trim away the overhang. The result should be two pieces that curve along with the last‚Äôs sole and mirror the taper and flare of the feather edge.



A still life of my workshop table in my favourite state: mid-task, with tools scattered everywhere. This shot shows the blocked insoles trimmed to the feather edge of the last.


After trimming, I also bevelled the upper edge of the insole. Otherwise the harsh edge would be uncomfortable on my feet.
Now to create the structure that will allow the upper to be joined to the insole: the holdfast. The holdfast is formed by relief carving into the insole, defining a ridge that runs around the bottom of the foot.
I first marked the distance from the feather edge to where the outer edge of the holdfast should be. This distance is typically 5 mm, except it‚Äôs 10 mm at the crest of the inner waist (that is, the inside arch of the foot) and 7 mm at the outer waist, the toe, and the heel. Then I connected these points and used my dividers to mark a 6 mm strip around the whole insole.



The holdfast is 6 mm wide and encircles the entire foot. Some shoemakers anchor the heel in other ways, so this 360-degree holdfast is not ubiquitous. But I like my boots chunky, so this is what works for me!


Then, very carefully, I carved about 1.5 mm into the insole on either side of these lines. The channel around the inner line slopes downward downward from the centre of the insole, while around the outer line, I can just cut straight in from the outside edge.



For precision cutting like this, I find it useful to switch between a craft knife and a skiving knife. Having a strop on hand to keep the blades sharp is a must. Here the 1.5 mm deep holdfasts have been carved out of the 3 mm thick insole, and unlike my previous pair of boots, I didn‚Äôt cut through to the last at all! ü•≥


I believe the professionals like Carreducker use leather that‚Äôs 6 mm thick for their insoles. The extra thickness would give a bit more leeway in carving the holdfasts, but in terms of sturdiness, even these relatively shallow holdfasts haven‚Äôt let me down.
Soon, once the boots are lasted, I will stitch through the holdfasts and the uppers (and the welts‚Äîsee below!). To prepare for the stitching, I marked around the holdfast where the thread will pass through. The stitches should be spaced about 8 mm apart on the outside of the holdfast, so they‚Äôll cluster more tightly inside the curves of the toe and heel.



Both inside and outside curves have been marked to define where, soon, stitching will anchor welts and outers through the holdfast.


Finally, I used my welting awl (slightly curved) to punch holes through the holdfast at every line I marked. This‚Äôll make the stitching much easier later.









The welting awl punches the paths through the holdfast that the thread will follow.







All punched and ready for stitching!





(Shoe aficionados may have encountered the term ‚ÄúGoodyear welted‚Äù. Goodyear welting is related to hand welting, just the holdfast is made of canvas glued to the underside of the insole, not carved out of the insole itself.)

I cut two strips from the 3 mm veg tan leather, each 1.2 mm wide and 70 cm long.

On the skin side, a steep bevel is carved that will sit flush against the outer leather once the boot has been lasted.

title: Handmade derby boots 4: Lasting and welting
text:
Welting
Time for the number one trickiest part of the whole process: connecting the welt strips to the boots by stitching through them, the upper, and the holdfast.



I‚Äôd previously blocked the welts into curves by soaking them, shaping them into circles, and letting them dry. I also wear my old cycling gloves while welting, because the stitches need to be pulled tight, and without the gloves, the thread will cut into my skin.


I began attaching the welts at the inside waist of each boot, the least visible spot. For each stitch, I put my welting awl through a pre-existing hole in the holdfast and punched through the feather edge of the glued-down upper. Then I used a separate awl to perforate the welt strip in the right spot (having two awls was a lot easier than making my poor welting awl do all the work). Then I saddle stitched with curved upholstery needles through all those cumbersome layers.









Dual awl action: the welting awl is on the right, going through the holdfast and the outer, while my favourite straight awl on the left is opening up the corresponding spot in the welt.







It‚Äôs impossible to sew these welts with straight needles. The professionals use bristles, long bendy things, but these curved upholstery needles work OK for me.





It took me a full Saturday to welt both boots, partly because I snapped one of the upholstery needles‚Äîwhich should give you a sense of how much muscle this job takes‚Äîand I had to run out to the hardware shop to get another.



Another little still life moment halfway through the second boot. (I did most of the welting sitting on the floor.)


After the welts were all sewn on, I got them wet with a toothbrush and then hammered them down on both sides. Hammering from the bottom helps the bevelled ‚Äúseam allowance‚Äù to sit flush against the uppers, and hammering from the top helps the strip stick out at 90-ish degrees from the feather edge.









Both welts are on! This picture was taken before the welts were hammered flat, so they‚Äôre still angled toward the upper, the way they were sewn on.







After hammering, the welts stick out horizontally around the feather edge. The boots are really starting to come together!

title: Handmade derby boots 4: Lasting and welting
text:
Lasting
Now that I‚Äôve blocked the insoles and carved out the holdfasts, I‚Äôm finally ready to last the uppers‚Äîthat is, to pull the leather that‚Äôll cover the foot over the last and anchor it down.
(Supposedly one should be making boots on boot lasts that have higher ankles, but my previous pair of boots came out just fine on these basic shoe lasts, so ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄ)
I can tell which upper is destined for which last because when cutting out the pattern pieces, I left little triangles sticking out at the bottom of each piece that goes on the inside of the foot. (If you revisit the pictures in this previous post, it‚Äôs for this reason that some pattern pieces but not others have extra little triangles on their bottom edges!)
To begin, I drenched the lasts and the insides of the uppers in baby powder. The idea is that the powder will help the lasts slip out more easily after the boots have been built.
Next, I ‚Äúpre-lasted‚Äù the uppers by nailing them sparsely to the bottom of the last, not pulling too tight, just letting the leather get to know the shape it will take on before the hard work of proper lasting begins. I left the boots sitting like this for a couple days.



The pre-lasted boots, all done up with placeholder laces.


To anchor the back of the boot to the back of the last, when lasting my previous pair of boots, I had put one nail straight through the heel cap into the last. Seemingly this is a controversial practice, so I experimented with not doing it this time, but I regret that choice‚Äîthe heel of the last didn‚Äôt stay in place very well, there was too much vertical play, so lasting the heels was a challenge. (Maybe this is one reason why boot lasts can useful?) So, note to future self: for me, the heel nail is a good move.
I unfortunately fully forgot to take any pictures while actually lasting the boots! The process looked like this: me, hunched over an upside-down boot in my lap, using lasting pliers to yank on the bottom edge of the upper leather, pulling it as far toward the centre line as I could before nailing each bit in place. Even though it‚Äôs a lot of work, it does make you feel like a real cobbler.



After a lot of wrangling, I got the uppers pulled over the lasts and nailed in place.


As you can probably imagine, excess leather really bunches up around the toe and the heel, so those areas require extra care (and extra nails).



The nail density correlates directly with how tricky it is to get each section to lie flat at the feather edge! This view also shows clearly the little triangles sticking out from the upper‚Äôs lower edge on the inside of the foot.


Despite all those nails, the toes still turned out a bit puckered above the feather edge, but honestly I don‚Äôt really mind. All these organic ‚Äúimperfections‚Äù show that these boots came from the hands of an artisan and not from a machine.
After lasting, I glued down the edges of the uppers, and once the glue was dry, I pulled out the nails and skived the big pleats flat.1

text:
Footnotes


I wrote that nice resultative and then wondered, ‚ÄúIs skive a manner verb or a result verb?‚Äù (You can take the girl out of linguistics etc, etc.) Resultative constructions work (ish) for both kinds of verbs, so let‚Äôs throw a few more diagnostics from Beavers & Koontz-Garboden (2020) at skive and see what happens.

If skive is a result verb, we shouldn‚Äôt be able to deny its result. For example, ‚ÄúShane just broke the vase, but it is not broken‚Äù is no good. ‚ÄúI skived the pleats, but they‚Äôre not skived‚Äù also sounds pretty bad, and the more general ‚ÄúI skived the pleats, but nothing‚Äôs different about them‚Äù doesn‚Äôt work either. +1 to Result.
If skive is a result verb, we shouldn‚Äôt be able to delete its object. For example, ‚ÄúAll last night, Shane broke‚Äù isn‚Äôt good without ‚Äúthe vase‚Äù. So let‚Äôs try: ‚ÄúAll last night, I skived‚Äù. Actually seems OK? +1 to Manner.
If skive is a result verb, we shouldn‚Äôt be able to use out-prefixation. For example, ‚ÄúShane out-broke the other vase smashers‚Äù is pretty weird. But ‚ÄúI out-skived the other leatherworkers‚Äù is OK to me. +1 to Manner.
If skive is a manner verb, only a particular kind of actor should be able to do it. (In contrast, result verbs are OK in both ‚ÄúShane broke the vase‚Äù and ‚ÄúThe vase broke‚Äù). And ‚ÄúThe leather skived‚Äù is definitely bad. +1 to Manner.
If skive is a manner verb, it should be bad when followed by ‚Äúbut didn‚Äôt move a muscle‚Äù, because probably an action is involved. ‚ÄúI skived the leather but didn‚Äôt move a muscle‚Äù üëéüèª. +1 to Manner.

So I guess skive is overall fairly well-Mannered, but with a bit of spice when it comes to result entailment?‚Ü©Ô∏é

title: Handmade derby boots 5: Midsoles and outsoles
text:
Filling in the insole
Picking up where we left off, with the boot freshly welted, the bottom of the foot isn‚Äôt quite level: the middle sits several millimetres lower than the sole‚Äôs perimeter. Not so good as a surface to glue a midsole onto! So the first thing to do is to build up the hollow centre so the surface is even.
It‚Äôs at this stage that some shoemakers will attach a shank: a stiff piece of metal, wood, or sole bend leather that sits beneath the arch and keeps the shoe from collapsing. A shank is crucial if the shoe will have a substantial heel drop, but for a flat style like this one, I‚Äôve found that my boots hold up just fine without. So I just filled up the sole with a hodgepodge of scrap leather.



It was very pleasing to finally use some of the oddly-shaped bits from my scrap hoard!

title: Handmade derby boots 5: Midsoles and outsoles
text:
The midsole
With the bottom of the foot nice and flat, the midsole can now be glued on.
I cut generous midsoles out of 3 mm veg tan leather, a few millimetres larger than the circumference of the welt all around. Then I used my roughening tool (Carreducker call it the ‚Äúkiller toothbrush‚Äù) to scratch up the skin side so that it‚Äôs more receptive to glue and (hopefully) won‚Äôt rub against the insole leather and start to squeak.



The killer toothbrush makes short work of the midsole‚Äôs skin side üò¨


Then I glued the midsoles onto the boots, skin side up, and carefully trimmed the edges down to match the exact circumference of the welts.



Midsoles are on and trimmed! The goal of the masking tape above the welt is to protect the upper leather during the soling process.


Time to stitch!






I used my dividers to mark a stitching line about 3 mm from the edge of the welt.







Following this line with a tracing wheel from my sewing kit, I can get evenly-spaced marks. They‚Äôre denser than they need to be, though, so‚Ä¶







‚Ä¶ I used my stitching awl to punch through every second one. This photo also shows where the two ends of the welt meet at the inside waist. The sole stitching will span this join and hold the two ends together.











I saddle stitched through the welt and midsole. After wrestling with the welts, the sole stitching is a relief!







With the sole stitching complete, the midsoles are attached with both glue and thread.





As an aside: at this point, I can most clearly illustrate why the hand-welted construction is so good for resoling. Should these boots ever need resoled, it‚Äôs this thread that would be cut through to detach the midsole from the uppers. But the welts would stay in place, and therefore so would the uppers, since they‚Äôre sandwiched in between the welts and the holdfasts. The fit of the shoe would therefore also stay exactly the same. Compare this to a stitchdown construction, where the upper is sewn directly onto the midsole, with no mediating welt. There, undoing those stitches means that the upper is free-floating and would need to be lasted again to be sewn onto the new sole, and re-lasting the upper could potentially change the shoes‚Äô fit.
OK, back onto the rails! The last step before moving on to the outsole is to finish the exposed leather of the welt and the midsole. I like leaving the veg tan undyed, because it ages and takes colour so beautifully through wear, but I did sand it down and then burnish it for some light protection using Tokonole.






Tokonole is a burnishing paste containing glue that sinks into the leather fibre and wax that polishes to a lovely shine on the surface.







In the left half of this picture, the sole edges are still raw; on the right, they‚Äôve been lightly burnished with Tokonole and a canvas cloth. The new saturated colour is so beautiful.





I applied the Tokonole on top of the welts and all around the soles‚Äô perimeters. Because those surfaces are flat, I had most success burnishing them with a piece of canvas cloth rather than the burnisher tool.



Et voila, sole stitching and edge finishing are complete!


Note: Because I‚Äôm applying a sole unit that covers the entire bottom of the foot, I attached the midsole with its skin side up. But if I were applying smaller, separate sole pieces that left some of the midsole exposed, I would have attached it skin side down and used Tokonole to finish any parts left uncovered.

title: Handmade derby boots 5: Midsoles and outsoles
text:
The outsole
Speaking of the sole unit, here‚Äôs what we‚Äôre working with:



A proper Vibram sole unit‚ÄîI decided to treat myself.


I intentionally ordered sole units that are a bit oversized‚Äîsize 41/42 for my 39/40‚Äîso that the width would be right. But of course, they‚Äôre a bit too long, so I had to trim the toe and heel down to the true size of the boot, which I traced on with silver pen.



Trimming the sole units down to size was really hard work! My triceps were sore for a good few days afterward. Another tricky thing is that the rubber can‚Äôt really be sanded down, so all the cuts have to be as smooth as possible. (Let‚Äôs call the jagged, angular cuts on the heel my signature look‚Ä¶)


Once the outsoles were the right size, I glued them onto the flesh side of the midsoles.






This water-based glue is fine to hold things in place temporarily, but it‚Äôs definitely not strong enough on its own to attach the outsoles permanently.







To secure the outsole properly, I used a bunch of brass screws. Make sure not to screw into the last!





And now, with the soles all finished, the boots are ready to come off of the lasts! ü•≥ An enormous milestone!
With the last out, here‚Äôs how the insole looks from the top:



The insole still shows all the little nail holes from blocking and lasting. I think it‚Äôs really lovely. Another mark of the hand.


All the white dust in the picture above is the baby powder I added so that removing the last would be easier‚Äîand it worked!
One of the last steps is to cover up this raw insole with another shoe component with a silly name: the insock.



The insock is the bit of leather that‚Äôs actually in contact with the bottom of your foot. I like it when they‚Äôre a bit bigger than the sole so that they cover the gap between insole and boot lining. I conveniently found a couple insocks lying around that had been cut from the lining leather of my previous pair of boots. Thanks past Elizabeth!


I glued the insocks down inside the boots, and with that, they were done!
‚Ä¶ Or so I thought, until I took them walking on a hot day and the heels of the outsoles peeled off üôÉ I guess the temperatures softened the glue, and two screws weren‚Äôt enough to hold each heel on. So when I got home, I sent a bunch of screws down from the insole into the solid rubber around the outside of the heels.



In a perfect world, I‚Äôd have screwed the heel on before gluing down the insock. But this solution is surprisingly fine‚Äîmy feet don‚Äôt notice the screw heads at all.


OK, and with that, they really are done ü•∞



My newest pride and joy: a finished pair of handmade derby boots.Ô∏è


Creating my own shoes is magic.
I really used to think it was normal that a new pair of leather shoes would cause months of blisters and pain before they started feeling okay. Making shoes has shown me that commercial footwear just isn‚Äôt made for feet shaped like mine. Which is wild, because my feet are so normal?! I could go on about that for a long time, but suffice it to say: what a difference to put on my beautiful bespoke, handmade boots. They fit perfectly right away. And with the right care, they‚Äôll last me forever. Magic, I say!
Thanks for following along ‚ù§Ô∏è

title: Bio

Bio
I grew up in Canada on Treaty 6 territory. My postsecondary journey began with a year living in beautiful Nelson, BC, on the traditional unceded territory of the Ktunaxa Nation, to study textile arts. Then I went on to pursue another love: language.
I completed a BA (Hons.) in Linguistics & German Language and Literature at the University of Alberta, then I moved to Germany for an MA in Linguistics at the Humboldt-Universit√§t zu Berlin and an MSc in Cognitive Systems: Language, Learning, and Reasoning at the Universit√§t Potsdam.

How many hours per task type?
My work fell into five broad categories:

Admin: Covers misc set-up and bureaucracy around the PhD, as well as my admin tasks within my research group.
Community: Covers reading groups, talk series, and conferences/workshops.
Coursework: Covers the required courses that were a condition of my funding as well as courses I audited for fun.
Research: Covers reading the literature, designing and implementing experiments and models, writing everything up, preparing talks, and the PhD examination process.

The Word segmentation project (red, Chapter 2) was my first-year project, and it grew up to become Pankratz et al., (2024). For this project, I ran one experiment in July 2022. The manuscript was submitted in late 2022, and the splashes of red in 2023 were the revisions following peer review. Then in early 2024 came the final formatting checks, and then the paper was out!
The Rule learning project (yellow, Chapter 3), which I did together with Aislinn Keogh, is the longest-running project of the four. We ran two experiments, one in April 2023 and one almost a year later in March 2024. This project never got published, but it appears as a chapter in each of our PhD theses.
The Rule generalisation project (green, Chapter 4) consumed my time and my thinking for much of 2023 and well into 2024. I consider it the heart of my PhD‚Äîit‚Äôs the project I find the most interesting and the most compelling. Which explains why I spent 661 hours on it! The project did have some false starts, though. I ran one experiment for it in October 2022, but that experiment never saw the light of day because of confounds in the design that I detected too late. A second experiment, the one that actually appears in the thesis, was run in July 2023.
Finally, the Rule structure generalisation project (blue, Chapter 5) was my main focus in my final year. For this project, I ran four experiments within three months: one in June 2024, two in August, and one in September. Those four experiments were all pretty similar, but still, four experiments in three months is serious progress, considering I spent my entire first year on one single experiment! Turns out a PhD does actually teach you things. Who knew?

title: An experiment in building student teams
text: In a course I‚Äôm co-organising, Data Analysis for Psychology in R 3, students collaborate on a final team project. This post is about how those teams are formed.

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: (1) Students select which course group/lab they‚Äôre in
text:
(1) Students select which course group/lab they‚Äôre in
For example, in DAPR, students can only form teams with other people who are in their same lab.
Technically this information is available on Learn, but it‚Äôs usually not up-to-date and doesn‚Äôt include people who aren‚Äôt yet officially enrolled.
This is a multiple choice question with only one possible choice.

title: An experiment in building student teams
text:
(2) Students enter preferred teammates‚Äô UUNs
Ask students to give you up to (team size ‚Äì 1) UUNs of the people they want to work with.
Your life will be easier if you implement this as (team size ‚Äì 1) optional free-text fields. (When we gave students a single free-text field and asked them to enter up to four UUNS separated by commas, they sometimes entered way more than four UUNs and used all kinds of delimiters.)

title: An experiment in building student teams
text:
(3) Students rank own availability/working times
Ask students to rank different time windows according to when they think they‚Äôll likely work on this project. I didn‚Äôt use this information in the gropu allocation, but it might help the teams self-organise.
The time options I gave students:

Monday to Friday (during the day)
Monday to Friday (evenings)
Saturday and Sunday (during the day)
Saturday and Sunday (evenings)

(I also added a note saying ‚ÄòWe don‚Äôt expect you to work on weekends, but since some of you might anyway, we include it as an option‚Äô)

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: (4) Students rank own project skills and collaboration skills
text:
(4) Students rank own project skills and collaboration skills
Work out a list of skills that the team project will require, and also include a few teamwork/collaboration-based soft skills. But keep it mostly focused on content skills (I had too many collaboration skills, which students generally put way higher than the project skills).
For example, next year for DAPR3 I will probably use skills like: - Coding in R - Making plots - Planning a statistical analysis - Interpreting a statistical analysis - Staying ahead of deadlines - Managing/organising a project - Communicating ideas through writing - Responding quickly to messages from teammates
In the version of this survey I asked my minidiss group to fill out, I also included other skills like: - Communicating ideas visually (because of the poster component) - Making sense of academic literature (because of the lit review component)
Have students rank these skills from strongest (could teach somebody else) to least strong (could learn from somebody else).

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: (5) Students select preferred mode(s) of communication
text:
(5) Students select preferred mode(s) of communication
A multiple choice question that lets students select multiple options. Options I used:

University e-mail
Microsoft Teams
SMS/messaging app (e.g., Whatsapp, Signal, Telegram)

Like the work times, I didn‚Äôt use this information in the team allocation process, but it may prove useful as the teams self-organise.

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: Optional free text field for further info
text:
Optional free text field for further info
Important for edge cases, e.g.,

people who have adjustments and wish to work alone
people who aren‚Äôt officially enrolled in the course yet for whatever reason
people who have permission from COs to work in smaller teams

title: An experiment in building student teams
text:
Data cleaning

If the same student submitted the form more than once, keep only the most recent response.

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: Group students together who‚Äôve written down each others‚Äô UUNs
text:
Group students together who‚Äôve written down each others‚Äô UUNs
Some students won‚Äôt have chosen anybody. We‚Äôll call these the singletons, and we‚Äôll set them aside until the next step.
Iterate over the students who did put down UUNs they want to work with.

For each student i:

For each of their chosen UUNs j:

Put i and j in a temp-group together if j also chose i.



Record each of the temp-groups that emerge through this mutual choosing process. If a student‚Äôs UUN has already been added to a temp-group, then they don‚Äôt need to be looked at again. As such, the process goes surprisingly quickly. And through this process, people will nearly always be teamed up with at least one person they chose.
An exception I observed: Student A only chose one other person, Student B, but B was already in a fully mutual five-by-five mapping with four other students. I gave the fully mutual five-by-five team priority. And I could resolve the case for Student A because luckily, there was a Student C who had asked to work with Student A. So this allowed us to say: ‚Äúyou are in a team with at least one person you chose and/or with at least one person who wanted to work with you‚Äù.
When the process above results in a temp-group of the maximum size, then you can finalise that team.
(Sometimes the process resulted in a temp-group that exceed the max size, because I was sloppy about data entry. If you limit the number of UUNs that can be entered, then you won‚Äôt have this problem. I solved it by splitting the too-big temp-group into two smaller temp-groups.)
If the process results in temp-groups that are smaller than the desired size, then we merge temp-groups and add in singletons (people who didn‚Äôt enter any UUNs they wanted to work with) based on their skill rankings.

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: Diversifying top-ranked skills in each temp-group
text:
Diversifying top-ranked skills in each temp-group
Consider which skills you really want at least one person in each team to be good at. These are your prioritised skills. For us, it was the stats-related skills as well as staying on top of deadlines.
For each temp-group, look at the top n skills from each current member. Also look at each singleton‚Äôs top n skills.
Where you can merge temp-groups with different top skills, do so. And where a singleton has different top skills than a temp-group, add them in.
It won‚Äôt always be possible, but do your best to group people so that all of your prioritised skills will appear somewhere in each team‚Äôs top n skills.

title: An experiment in building student teams
section: Top up temp-groups with remaining folks from Learn
text:
Top up temp-groups with remaining folks from Learn
Not everyone completed the form, so we don‚Äôt have skills data for everybody.
If possible, use the non-responders to top up temp-groups that are only missing one member. This way, if the non-responder is a no-show, the team will only be down one member.
Another option would be to just team up all the non-responders together. But we are dealing with people who haven‚Äôt filled out a well-publicised form by the deadline, so they‚Äôre probably less invested than the average student. So, grouping all the non-responders together would not really set that team up for success.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
A post for reference! This is a checklist of every step in my process for making hand-welted leather boots and shoes.
But first, a proud shoe mama moment: I used this checklist to guide my latest project, these barefoot-style derby boots.
OK! A few general notes on this step-by-step checklist:

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Prepping stiffeners

Cut heel counter and toe puff from 2‚Äì3mm thick veg tan leather.
Glass the skin sides of both stiffeners.
For the heel counter, skive only the upper edge down to nothing. Leave the lower edge with a bit more thickness (this‚Äôll make it easier to push the stiffener up in between the lining and the outer later on, and the feather edge can be cut and smoothed down once the heel counter is in place).
For the toe puff, skive all edges down to nothing. The thinner the long side (that‚Äôll end up at the feather edge), the easier it‚Äôll be to last.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
section: Clicking (aka cutting out the pattern pieces) and prepping upper pieces
text:
Clicking (aka cutting out the pattern pieces) and prepping upper pieces

Write a list of all pattern pieces (listing both left and right pieces makes forgetting a piece, or forgetting to mirror one, less likely). For a pair of derby boots, we‚Äôve got:

Outer leather:

Toe cap (L, R)
Vamp (L, R)
Quarters (L, L, R, R)
Back strip (L, R)
Tongue (L, R)

Lining leather:

Vamp (L, R)
Quarters (L, L, R, R)
Back strip (L, R)
Insock (L, R)


Map out the natural stretch structure of the outer and lining leather, and mark any blemishes.
Lay out pattern pieces on leather, matching directions of stretch. Reserve the best leather for the vamps (most visible) and the least nice bits for the tongue and insock (least visible).
Trace pieces onto leather with silver pen.
Cut out pieces just inside silver lines.
Skive areas of over/underlay.
If dyeing public sides of leather, use a few coats of aniline dye, followed by dye sealer, followed by Tokonole.
Transfer pattern markings (e.g., alignment points, lasting allowances).
Outer: Burnish all edges that‚Äôll end up as a single layer (e.g., tongue edge, lower curve overlay on quarters, overlay on toe cap, overlay edges of back strip, overlay of vamp over tongue).

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
section: Closing (aka attaching outers and linings to create the upper)
text:
Closing (aka attaching outers and linings to create the upper)

Join toe cap and vamp

Sew outer toe cap to outer vamp.
Apply reinforcement tape over seam on flesh side.



Join spine of quarters

Outer and lining quarters: Sew spine of quarters together edge to edge.
Apply reinforcement tape over seam on flesh side.
Outer and lining back strip, quarters: Sew back strip to quarters, centered over spine seam.
Apply reinforcement tape over seams on flesh side.



Join outer/lining quarters

Outer quarters: Run reinforcement tape around topline and lacing edges of quarters (to reinforce where lacing holes will be punched).
Outer and lining quarters: Flesh sides together, cement quarters together just along topline and lacing edges (leaving the layers separate below, so that later, the heel stiffener can be sandwiched in between).


If bellows tongue:

Bellows tongue and quarters: Cement lacing edges of bellows tongue to lacing edges of quarters lining.
Bellows tongue and quarters: Sew bellows tongue to quarters along topline/lacing edge. If back strip includes bootstrap, tack it down inside the boot as part of this seam.
Quarters: Burnish topline and lacing edges.
Quarters: Punch lacing holes and add grommets/hooks.
Quarters: Sew another seam through bellows tongue/lining/outer quarters on other side of eyelets, to reduce strain on lacing holes.



If regular tongue:

Quarters: Sew outer and lining together around topline/lacing edges. If back strip includes bootstrap, tack it down inside the boot as part of this seam.
Quarters: Burnish topline and lacing edges.
Quarters: Punch lacing holes, add grommets/hooks.




Join tongue (both regular and bellows) and vamp

Outer and lining vamp: Flesh sides together, cement outer to lining ONLY along the convex curves that will be joined to the quarters, leaving tongue overlay unglued.
Vamp, tongue: Sandwich the tongue‚Äôs underlay in between vamp outer and vamp lining, and sew it in place through all three layers.



Join vamp and quarters

Align quarters over vamp using markings transferred from pattern.
Quarters lining: cut a 12mm slit about 20mm back along the curve that overlays the vamp, so that the vamp can be sandwiched between the quarters outer and quarters lining.
Cement quarters to vamp along this curve.
Sew through all layers.

The uppers are done! üíÉ

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Insole and welt prep

Cut insole based on last sole pattern, with a few mm of ease on all sides, from sturdy veg tan (minimum 3mm thick).
Glass skin side of insole.
Wet insole, block it (skin side up) to last sole with nails and allow to mostly dry.
Cut welts: two strips 12mm wide, approx 70 cm long, from the same leather that will be used for the midsole later (I use 3mm veg tan).
Prepare welts (on flesh side: cut the shallow stitching valley 5mm from feather edge side; on skin side: cut the 5mm-wide under-feather-edge taper).
If dyeing sole edges later, dye tapered edge of welt now.
Trim blocked insole to last‚Äôs feather edge, and bevel raised bits around feather edge flat.
Mark 6mm wide holdfast all around foot circumference (10mm from feather edge at toe and heel, 7mm at inside waist, 5mm elsewhere).
Carve holdfast about 1.5mm deep.
Mark hole spacing around holdfast (holes every 7mm, measured around outer circumference of holdfast).
Pre-punch holes in holdfast using waxed welting awl (not stitching awl).

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Lasting

Cover last and inside of uppers with baby powder.
Last the linings, placing nails outside holdfast.
Cement lasted lining down onto holdfast.
Trim lining down to holdfast inner edge and skive down pleats at toe and heel.
Paste stiffeners on using Hirschkleber. (For heel counter, can apply just a bit of paste initially and use rounded screwdriver to persuade heel counter up in between outer and lining, then add more paste later once the stiffener is in position. Toe puff is a lot easier by comparison.)
Skive down pleats in stiffeners.
Last the outers over the stiffeners.
Cement outer leather down onto holdfast (PVA glue works well here).
Once glue is dry, remove lasting nails.
Trim outer down to holdfast inner edge and skive down pleats at toe and heel.
Dye skived bits to the same colour as the outer, just in case they are visible after welting.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Welting

Trace feather edge using silver pen.
Sew on welts through holdfast and lasted uppers, aiming for the welting awl to exit upper at the feather edge line.
Wet welts and hammer flat.
Fill in centre of holdfast with cork filler.
Hammer and rasp the sole surface down so it‚Äôs fairly smooth. Doesn‚Äôt need to be perfect.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Midsole

Use the circumference of the welted edge, plus a few mm ease, as a pattern to cut the midsole from 3mm veg tan.
Rough both skin side and flesh side of midsole.
Cement flesh side of midsole onto sole surface.
If using a fudge wheel, apply fudging to welt.
Mark stitching line about 4mm in from edge of welt.
Pre-punch welt stitching holes using stitching awl (not welting awl), taking care not to damage upper.
Sew welt and midsole together.
If midsole still overhangs welt, trim edge down. Doesn‚Äôt need to be perfect‚Äîwill sand all edges down later.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
If building stacked leather heel

Take heel pattern off of midsole bottom.
Cut heel lift(s) from same leather as midsole.
Cement (using Renia Colle de Cologne) + peg (with pegging awl + wooden toothpicks) each successive heel lift layer.
Trim heel stack down to edge of midsole.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Rubber sheet soling

Take soling pattern(s) off of trimmed midsole/heel.
Cut rubber outsole pieces, including a bit of ease.
Rough the midsole leather and the upper face of the outsole.
Cement midsole and soling rubber together (two coats of Colle de Cologne); bind tightly with bike tubes/fabric strips for min 12h.
For extra security, fix rubber soling to midsole/welt using short tacks (esp useful at heel and toe).

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Edge finishing

Once cement has set, trim down outsole rubber as much as possible.
Carefully sand down welt/midsole/outsole edges. I like to taper the sanding in at the inner waist to make an elegant curve.
Bevel welt‚Äôs upper edge.
Remove dried glue bits from welt/sole edges with rubber crepe.
If dyeing edges, apply dye and dye sealer.
If needed, touch up dye on upper too.
Burnish welt/sole edges with Tokonole and canvas cloth.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Finishing

Remove the last! Try on the shoe! Celebrate!
If extra heel security is needed: Hammer tacks from top of insole into heel stack.
If adding lacing loop to tongue: Lace up boots, mark desired point on tongue to attach the loop, and then sew on a strip of leather (each strip about 12mm wide by 36‚Äì48mm long).
Cement insock to top of insole, in three phases: first the heel (easiest to reach and align), then midfoot (can slide insock forward, using cemented heel as an anchor), and finally the hard-to-reach forefoot.


All done ü•æüë¢üëûü•Ç‚ú®

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Attaching the midsole

Use the circumference of the welted edge, plus a few mm ease, as a pattern to cut the midsole from 3mm veg tan.
Rough both skin side and flesh side of midsole.
Cement flesh side of midsole onto sole surface.
If using a fudge wheel, apply fudging to welt.
Mark stitching line about 4mm in from edge of welt.
Pre-punch welt stitching holes using stitching awl (not welting awl), taking care not to damage upper.
Sew welt and midsole together.
If midsole still overhangs welt, trim edge down. Doesn‚Äôt need to be perfect‚Äîwill sand all edges down later.

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
Attaching the rubber sheet soling

Take soling pattern(s) off of trimmed midsole/heel.
Cut rubber outsole pieces, including a bit of ease.
Rough the midsole leather and the upper face of the outsole.
Cement midsole and soling rubber together (two coats of Colle de Cologne); bind tightly with bike tubes/fabric strips for min 12h.
For extra security, fix rubber soling to midsole/welt using short tacks (esp useful at heel and toe).

title: Shoemaking step-by-step
text:
The final steps

Remove the last! Try on the shoe! Celebrate!
If extra heel security is needed: Hammer tacks from top of insole into heel stack.
If adding lacing loop to tongue: Lace up boots, mark desired point on tongue to attach the loop, and then sew on a strip of leather (each strip about 12mm wide by 36‚Äì48mm long).
Cement insock to top of insole, in three phases: first the heel (easiest to reach and align), then midfoot (using the cemented heel bit as an anchor, slide insock forward over insole), and finally the hard-to-reach forefoot.
